bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 27, 1901

div1.p: Reed teases Emilie Lawrence Reed. His colleague McConnell will be visiting her. Reed mentions a drawing of mosquitos.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, January 27, 1901
div1.opener:
A Kiss
to Dooges.
Columbia Barracks,
January 27th,
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
Just as
I was getting ready to write
a short letter to the dearest
woman in the world, I
had a visitor come in
and as he was just the
longest-winded individ-
ual that you ever did
hear of, I thought that he
would never go- So here
it is eleven P.M. o'clock
and no letter written, and
dear Sis Gouty sitting at
that end of the line and
quarrelling for dear life
because her Mr Mantee
doesn't write ten letters
per week! What is a poor
man to do under the cir-
cumstances? Dr McConnell
left here, this afternoon,
on the Transport Rawlins
and should reach Washington
about next Friday or Sat-
urday- I have asked him
to drop over to see you
and “just tell you that you
saw me, but did not see
me saw”! I thought you
might like to see some
one who had recently
seen me- When I come,
I will bring over the draw-
ings that he made for
me and let you see
old Lady Fasciatus
and her good old Man!
He has executed them
beautifully- You have yet
written and told me what
kind of a present you want
me to bring you. Why don't
you hurry up, you fat,
sweet, gouty joy?- I hope
that your darling spirits
are flowing in a jollier
vein than when you last
wrote and that the beef-steak
is a little more tender than
when you last wrote.
Last night, you would
have smiled to see me
almost freezing under
a big, heavy blanket and
my over-coat- The temper-
ature went down to 50°-
Just think of that! And
it was dreadfully cold!
I shouldn't be surprised
if I wouldn't have to stay
in doors from the time I come
till april 1st! Have you got
a buffalo-overcoat that I
could put on? Hows is
darling lumpkin daughter?
Going to school again and
learning her lessons well
like a sweet precious Lamb?
How father does want to
see his darling girls again!
But they must be cheerful
and musn't quarrel about
boarding-house fare!
Oh! My! oh! moo! Hoo!
Hoo! “oysters for two”!
Good-night, you sweet joys
and pleasant dreams of
pleasant scenes- Boo!
Boo! to you, Miss Lumpkin-
Kisses & love for my precious
babies-
